It is the longest and widest single nerve in the human body and provides sensation to the skin of the foot, as well as the entire lower leg (except for its inner side). The tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve, supplies sensation to the sole of the foot, while the common fibular nerve supplies sensation to the lower leg and upper surface of the foot. The sciatic nerve also provides the connection to the nervous system for the skin of the leg, the muscles of the back of the thigh, and those of the leg and foot. It is derived from spinal nerves L4 to S3 and contains fibers from both the anterior and posterior divisions of the lumbosacral plexus.

Additionally, the sciatic nerve can be blocked at different locations, such as the popliteal fossa, where it divides into its two branches: the tibial and the common peroneal nerve. This information deepens the understanding of the sciatic nerve's role in providing sensation and connection to the nervous system for the foot, and also highlights its clinical relevance in procedures such as popliteal blocks for surgeries on the ankle, Achilles tendon, or foot.

The sciatic nerve is a large nerve that begins in the lower back and runs through the buttock and down the lower limb, all the way to the foot on the posterior aspect. It is the longest and widest single nerve in the human body and provides sensation to the skin of the foot, as well as the entire lower leg (except for its inner side). The tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve, supplies sensation to the sole of the foot, while the common fibular nerve supplies sensation to the lower leg and upper surface of the foot. The sciatic nerve also provides the connection to the nervous system for the skin of the leg, the muscles of the back of the thigh, and those of the leg and foot. It is derived from spinal nerves L4 to S3 and contains fibers from both the anterior and posterior divisions of the lumbosacral plexus.

Additionally, the sciatic nerve can be blocked at different locations, such as the popliteal fossa, where it divides into its two branches: the tibial and the common peroneal nerve. This information deepens the understanding of the sciatic nerve's role in providing sensation and connection to the nervous system for the foot, and also highlights its clinical relevance in procedures such as popliteal blocks for surgeries on the ankle, Achilles tendon, or foot.

The sciatic nerve does not run directly in the foot, but it branches out into smaller nerves that innervate the foot, providing sensation and connection to the nervous system for the skin and muscles of the foot.

The nerve provides connection to the nervous system for nearly the whole skin of the leg, the muscles of the back of the thigh, and those of the leg and foot. It is derived from spinal nerves L4 to S3 and contains fibers from both the anterior and posterior divisions of the lumbosacral plexus. The actual spinal cord terminates between vertebrae L1 and L2, and the nervous tissue that extends below this point collectively forms the cauda equina. The sciatic nerve runs through the back of each leg and into the feet. The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and passes through the popliteal fossa to pass below the arch of soleus. The sciatic nerve is located in the gluteus maximus muscle, and it can be blocked at different locations, affecting its two branches: the tibial and the common peroneal nerve.
